instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.SMC_BCACOK: What is SMC_BCACOK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK When you see SMC_BCACOK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
Previous work done on this one.
at first, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and PP3V42

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was poorly soldered, replaced it just to be sure.

No green light. Checked with three different I/O boards.
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is hovering somewhere between 0 and 1.2V.
<SIGNAL>SMC_BCACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.2V

I've replaced the SMC, but the one I used was in a poor state (looked like crap). I only had one donor board and it looked like shit.
I'm waiting on another donor to arrive, but was wondering if the SMC is a sure thing with the above info or if there's anything else to check?

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
You don't need to connect LIO board until get correct value for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, 8.4-8.5V.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V, 19KOhm
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0V, 10KOhm
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0V, 97.8KOhm
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>. 20mV, 7.1MOhm

Had some trouble figuring out where <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> was generated, as the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pdf shows it as an INPUT for the SMC. Checked a pdf for another one and found out its actually generated by the SMC...

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
Check basic SMC voltages and signals; block (2 of 2) on page 40.
Also check PCH's RTC signals.
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03 fail a lot on this board.

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
I was missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>, but it turns out <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> was missing from the board. Placed one on the board which restored it, but not done yet. Current measurements: [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]

 		[/TR]

 			[TD="align: left"]10k[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]

 			[TD="align: left"]97,8k[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]20mV[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]7,1M[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"] [/TD]

 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>[/TD]

 		[/TR]
[TR]

 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"] [/TD]

 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,4V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,3V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"] [/TD]

 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]1,19V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,4V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,1V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]1,2V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0,2-0,5V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"][B]<CHIP>U1800</CHIP>[/B][/TD]

 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]26KOhm[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]20KOhm[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]108KOhm[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]

 			[TD="align: left"]7MOhm[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is at 0V. I though it was present because <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> was there, but I see the two arent directly related. I'll see if I can find out why <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> isnt there next.

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> will not work until <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> appears.
Try a known good SMC from other 3208 board...

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message: Thanks man. Will do as soon as I get my hands on one.

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message: Haven't been able to find a 3208 yet, so I''ll wait until one comes along. I did, as a test, place an SMC from an 3209. Logicboard works fine after that, so its safe to assume that itll work with a 3209 SMC just as well. Feel free to mark this solved and thanks for the help!

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message: At least run ASD and see if some error pops out...

threads.title: 820 3208 - no green light, liquid damage
threads.message: Already did. there are no errors, but I'm told the firmware on this SMC is slightly different and may cause software issues in the future. I already have a functional original board lying around now. Just to be sure, I'll keep the one with the wrong SMC and give the one with the proper SMC to the customer. Then, when I come across the right SMC, I'll place that. Or, I'll just keep the board as is and use it when I need to test stuff.
